Title.evidence: Preoperative Enema in Anal Surgery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either a preoperative enema (n=133) or no enema (n=133).

Participants.evidence: adults aged 20â€“85 years with grade III or IV haemorrhoids or anal fistulas. Conducted at Taipei Medical University Shuang-Ho Hospital, Taiwan

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either a preoperative enema (n=133) or no enema (n=133).

Objective.evidence: aimed to evaluate the efficacy of preoperative enemas in anal surgeries

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative pain measured by the visual analogue scale (VAS) from day 0 to day 7.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Surgeons and data analysts were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either a preoperative enema (n=133) or no enema (n=133). Conducted at Taipei Medical University Shuang-Ho Hospital, Taiwan, between November 2022 and August 2023

Result_Outcome.evidence: no significant differences were found in VAS scores, analgesic consumption, or complications between groups.

Harms.evidence: Secondary outcomes included postoperative complications such as infection, bleeding, and urinary retention.
